abstract.text: A view that can be rendered by any backend.

production ready variadic generics.

implementation. Haters may see this as a
composition lover re-implementing inheritance; I see it as innovation.
A container that presents rows of data arranged in columns.
A control that initiates an action.
Constrains a view to maintain an aspect ratio matching that of the
provided size.
A view with exactly 2 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A navigation primitive that appends a value to the current navigation path on click.
A view that arranges its subviews vertically.
A 2-D shape that can be drawn as a view.
Gets the view’s children as a type-erased collection of view graph nodes. Type-erased
to avoid leaking complex requirements to users implementing their own regular views.
Sets the color of the foreground elements displayed by this view.
The default
implementation. Haters may see this as a
composition lover re-implementing inheritance; I see it as innovation.
A view with exactly 1 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A rounded rectangle whose corner radius is equal to half the length of its shortest side.
A view used by
to support non-exhaustive if statements.
A flexible space that expands along the major axis of its containing
stack layout, or on both axes if not contained in a stack.
Positions this view within an invisible frame having the specified minimum size constraints.
Creates the view’s widget using the supplied backend.
A view that is scrollable when it would otherwise overflow available space. Use the
modifier to constrain height if necessary.
Alignment of items layed out along the horizontal axis.
A view that displays a root view and enables you to present additional views over the root view.
An axis in a 2D coordinate system.

Prevents text field submissions from propagating to this view’s

A control for selecting a value from a bounded range of numerical values.
A control that displays an editable text interface.

A control for editing multiline text.

A placeholder view used by elementary
implementations which don’t have bodies. Fatally

The view’s content (composed of other views).

is
, then a backend-specific default value

because overload resolution didn’t
like the double default parameters.
A button that shows a popover menu when clicked.
Adds an action to perform when the user taps or clicks this view.

to support if/else conditional statements.
A control for selecting from a set of values.

Used as the body of
to end the chain of view bodies.
Disables user interaction in any subviews that support disabling
interaction.
A view that displays an image.
A view which attempts to persist the state of its view subtree even
when the subtree’s structure changes. Uses state serialization (via
view graph snapshotting) to persist view state even when a child
view’s implementation gets swapped out with an implementation from
a newly-loaded dylib (this is what makes this useful for hot reloading).
Sets the style of the toggle.

is
, then a backend-specific
default value is used.
Constrains a view to maintain a specific aspect ratio.
A rounded rectangle.
A control for toggling between two values (usually representing on and off).
Updates the view’s widget after a state change occurs (although the
change isn’t guaranteed to have affected this particular view).
is the size suggested by the parent container, but child
views always get the final call on their own size.
Forces any contained text to become emphasized. For text that uses
-based fonts, this means using the text style’s
emphasized weight. For all other text, this means using
Create cross-platform desktop apps for macOS, Linux, Windows, iOS and tvOS.
Starts a task before a view appears (but after
has been
accessed), and cancels the task when the view disappears.
Adds an action to perform when the user submits a text field within this
view (generally via pressing the Enter/Return key). Outer
handlers get called before inner
handlers. To prevent
submissions from propagating upwards, use
after
adding the handler.
A divider that expands along the minor axis of the containing stack layout
(or horizontally otherwise). In dark mode it’s white with 10% opacity, and
in light mode it’s black with 10% opacity.
Sets the font of contained text. Can be overridden by other font
modifiers within the contained view, unlike other font-related
modifiers such as
and
which override the font properties of all contained text.
A view that displays a variable amount of children.
A shape that has style information attached to it, including color and stroke style.
A view with exactly 9 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet

Alignment of items layed out along the vertical axis.
Configures the behavior in which scrollable content interacts with
the software keyboard.
Overrides the font weight of any contained text. Optional for
convenience. If given
, does nothing.
A view which erases the type of its child. Useful in dynamic
use-cases such as hot reloading, but not recommended if there
are alternate strongly-typed solutions to your problem since
has significantly more overhead than strongly
typed views.
A result builder used to compose views together into composite views in
a declarative manner.
Adds an action to run when this view is clicked. Any clickable elements
within the view will no longer be clickable.
A view with exactly 8 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet

, forces the style’s emphasized weight to be

A text view.
Adds padding to a view with a different amount for each edge.
A view that groups views together without affecting their layout (allowing
modifiers to be applied to a whole group of views at once).
Adds an action to be performed after this view disappears.
Positions this view within an invisible frame having the specified minimum size constraints.
